heading: motorola slows slide
subheading: all those layoffs are paying off. plus, the company is selling more cellular gear. also: unisys shows progress in its transition to computer services.
author: wired news report
text: motorola reported about a 60 percent decline in fourth-quarter operating profits late wednesday, but beat wall street estimates and said plans to improve profits with a massive restructuring are ahead of schedule. cost-cutting and improved sales in cellular phones and computer chips boosted the company's performance, analysts said.fourth-quarter net income was us$159 million, or 26 cents per share, down from $321 million, or 53 cents per share, including special charges. excluding special charges, operating earnings in the fourth quarter of 1997 were $393 million, or 65 cents per share. the consensus estimate from market researcher first call was 23 cents per share.despite the decline from year-ago levels, motorola's (mot) numbers were an improvement over results posted earlier in the year, when the technology and communications giant struggled to make a profit.cost-cutting boosted profits by about $210 million in the fourth quarter, and motorola said savings from a restructuring first announced last summer will reach $1 billion by mid-1999. more jobs will be lost, however. the company now plans to cut 18,000 jobs compared with the initial estimate of 15,000."the restructuring story is definitely building momentum," said lehman brothers analyst tim luke. "it looks like these numbers are very strong."motorola has also cut a lot of products from its huge array, but still managed to improve overall sales to $8.34 billion from $8.28 billion in the year-ago quarter. for the year, total sales were $29.4 billion, down from $29.8 billion in 1997.analysts said motorola made strong gains in digital cellular phone sales -- an area where it previously made mistakes by getting into the market late. sales of cellular products were $3.9 billion in the quarter, up from $3.6 billion a year ago. for the year, motorola sold $12.5 billion worth of cellular products, up from $11.9 billion in 1997.- - -new focus, new profit: unisys thursday posted a fourth-quarter net income of $139 million, up 60 percent from the year-ago quarter, as the long-time mainframe computer maker showed solid progress on its transformation into a computer services firm.the company earned 42 cents per diluted share in the fourth quarter compared to 25 cents per share before charges in the year-ago quarter, putting it 2 cents per share ahead of wall street's expectations as compiled by first call. revenue in the fourth quarter grew 8 percent to $2.05 billion from $1.90 billion a year ago.unisys (uis) said revenues in its information services business rose 15 percent in the quarter, with strong order gains. its global customer services unit grew 6 percent as double-digit growth in personal computer services offset a drop in mainframe maintenance revenue. its computer hardware business grew 3 percent in the quarter, weighed down by difficult comparisons after exiting the personal computer business last year.reuters contributed to this report.
